Maybe you've read a little about Mavo (if not, go to the [Mavo website](http://mavo.io) and learn more) and now you're ready to implement it. Awesome! Here's how to get started. In the head of the pages you want to use the Mavo script, add the following code: ``` ``` Now that you've connected the scripts, you need to connect the elements in the code with the scripts. To do that, you need to choose the element you want to use the Mavo functionality. If you're not sure what to do here, just put it on the outside wrapper of your code--I like to create a wrapper called `#app`--and set the following attribute on that element: `mv-app="nameofapp"` Here's an example: `
` Something to remember is that you should only use alphanumeric characters for your attribute values for Mavo. No hypens or underscores. Camel case is cool or all lowercase. Otherwise, it will cause issues with Mavo Expressions later on. Now you're app is connected to the script and everything inside that element is able to utilize Mavo. The next thing you need to add is a storage source. Mavo comes with a few storage options right out of the gate: - Local storage (the user's browser) - Github - Dropbox - Your own storage backend For the sake of brevity and ease of use, let's just choose local storage. So when you click on "Edit" in the Mavo toolbar you should be able to edit properties that you've specially marked with this attribute: `property="propertyname"` Remember the naming conventions. Let's say we want to add an editable `

``` Once you've added at least one property attribute to an element, you'll see the "Edit" button appear on the Mavo toolbar. Click that element and then hover over the `

` that you created. You'll see that it's not editable. Once you're finished, click the "Save" button and refresh the page. You'll see that your changes have persisted! The Mavo local storage option utilizes the localStorage API so that means that your changes will stay in the browser's storage even if you close the tab or the browser altogether. The only way to clear that storage is to use a script or manually remove the storage in your browser. That's the very basic gist of Mavo. This is a space to write about using Mavo, an exciting new front end editor that bolts onto any HTML website. It gives you the ability to edit and create content without a relational database or advanced scripting.

_This page is created and maintained using Mavo._

- Author in Markdown
- Connects to any site
- No database necessary
- Easy to deploy
- Fast
- Secure
- Plays nice with HTML
- Plays nice with SEO
